title: Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain scores twice, one of them a beauty, as Liverpool thrash game Genk
text:
He may have made his comeback from a serious knee injury five months ago, but Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain may finally consider his rehabilitation complete.

With two sublime goals against Genk, the Liverpool midfielder eased his side out of a discomfort zone in Belgium, while also offering a hint about the next stage of the European champions’ evolution.

Oxlade-Chamberlain, Naby Keita and Fabinho formed a midfield trio for the first time, the pragmatism of Jordan Henderson and Gini Wijnaldum sacrificed for what, by accident or design, amounted to a cavalry charge.

This was a Liverpool performance thrilling in attacking intensity but so deeply flawed in the defensive structure it was a throwback to those years prior to Virgil Van Dijk’s arrival. Stick in a DVD of Liverpool's 2013-14 season and it will fit seamlessly.

We should start with the positives of the 4-1 victory which keeps Liverpool on course for the knockout stage.

There was a moment at Old Trafford on Sunday when Oxlade-Chamberlain took possession 25 yards from goal, dropped the shoulder and played a timid sideways pass to a teammate.

On the touchline, Jurgen Klopp was enraged, the cameras picking up his screams urging his midfielder to drive forward and use the shooting power which prompted Liverpool to sign him.

With such instructions still giving him tinnitus, three days later Oxlade-Chamberlain took the direct route in the Genk Arena. It took him 151 seconds to score his first and he doubled his tally in more spectacular style after the interval.
description: He may have made his comeback from a serious knee injury five months ago, but Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain may finally consider his rehabilitation complete.
